Award.AwardTitle: Early Career and Student Support for "Mathematical Physics at the Crossings" Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide financial support for US participants in the conference "Mathematical Physics at the Crossings" to be held at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Virginia Tech), Blacksburg, VA, May 20-24, 2019. The conference focuses on recent developments in many-body quantum systems. These systems are of high relevance for the realization of the goals of the Quantum Leap initiative. The meeting will add momentum to the process of developing mathematical knowledge about the many-body quantum systems, potentially facilitating building quantum devices for medical, navigational, computational or other practical purposes. This award will give US-based students, early-career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, and researchers without other sources of support an opportunity to attend and participate in the conference. Information about the conference can be found at: http://www.math.vt.edu/HagedornFest/index.html

The international conference "Mathematical Physics at the Crossings" will gather researchers in mathematical physics, quantum information, and physics to discuss topics of current research regarding many-body quantum systems. The topics covered include adiabatic approximation with a focus on many-body quantum systems, many-body localization problems, molecular dynamics, and periodically driven quantum systems. Study of properties of interacting many-body quantum systems is one of the central problems in today condensed matter physics, and the available mathematical knowledge about this problem is minimal. The topic is also of significant interest for scholars working in areas of quantum information and quantum computation. This conference will bring together experts in the field and will expose graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to the latest research in this area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In May 2019, the primary investigators organized a mathematical physics conference "Mathematical Physics at the Crossings" at the Virginia Tech Blacksburg campus. The five-day conference focused on recent mathematical physics results related to quantum chemistry and quantum physics. The conference featured some of the most prominent US mathematical physics figures, but had plenty of space for early career academics to present their work as well. The award enabled us to support eleven U.S. based postdocs and PhD students in attending the conference. 

The conference helped disseminate knowledge and fostered new collaborations in four primary areas: adiabatic approximation, many-body localization, molecular dynamics, and periodically driven quantum systems. Each of these areas is highly relevant for making "The Quantum Leap: Leading the Next Quantum Revolution," one of the NSF's 10 Big Ideas. Participation of early career scientists in conferences is a crucial component of ensuring continuity of knowledge and initiation of the next generation into quantum mathematical physics. Several collaborations, both national and international, involving both senior and early career scientists, started during the conference. We expect that these collaborations will lead to new results in the field and in turn deepen our understanding of quantum mechanics. They would not have happened without the generous support of this award.

The event attracted attention to the Virginia Tech mathematical physics group and more broadly to mathematics research carried out in the Appalachian region. It was among a select few mathematical events that attracted talented early career researchers to the region. On the national level, the conference increased the visibility of the mathematical physics community, in particular its quantum mechanics subfield.
